gameDescription: In Operation Pollination, players commandeer advanced airships in a near future where the survival of bees and the global ecosystem is at stake. The game combines strategic decision-making with environmental conservation, focusing on the crucial role bees play in our world.

blueTeam.name: The Bombus Navigators
blueTeam.description: Specializing in sustainable habitat creation and conservation education.

redTeam.name: The Apis Aviators
redTeam.description: Experts in disaster recovery and population relocation.

turns.scenario: A devastating hurricane has laid waste to primary bee habitats and colonies. Decisions need to be made for recovery and restoration.

options.A: Plant native flowers in hurricane-affected areas to restore bee habitats.
options.B: Establish new bee colonies in safe zones, ensuring their survival post-disaster.

AA.narrative: Both teams prioritized habitat restoration in devastated areas. Bee populations begin returning, but their recovery is slow because natural habitats can't be rebuilt overnight.

AB.narrative: While one team focused on restoring habitats, the other successfully relocated existing colonies. This dual strategy helps boost recovery rates while new habitats mature.

BA.narrative: One team focused on relocation while the other initiated habitat restoration. This balance led to an accelerated recovery of bee populations in the area.

BB.narrative: Both teams set up new colonies in safe zones. This strategy ensured immediate survival for the species, but habitat restoration is still urgently needed.

turns.scenario: Wildfires have scorched whole regions, leaving the local bee population homeless.

options.A: Seed fire-ravaged areas with bee-friendly vegetation to encourage ecological recovery.
options.B: Create artificial bee habitats in unaffected regions to support displaced populations.

AA.narrative: Both teams opted to seed fire-ravaged areas with bee-friendly plants. These efforts fuelled the fast revival of plant ecosystems, promising brighter prospects for returning bees.

AB.narrative: One team planted vegetation while the other built artificial habitats. The synergy of these strategies provided bees with immediate shelter and long-term recovery prospects in the area.

BA.narrative: With one team focusing on artificial habitats and the other rehabilitating the landscapes, a great balance of immediate relief and long-term recovery created an optimal environment for bees.

BB.narrative: Both teams decided to establish artificial habitats. This provided immediate solutions for the displaced bee population, but the need for natural habitats still persists.

turns.scenario: There is a pressing need to expand bee habitats and boost their awareness and conservation on a larger scale.

options.A: Develop bee sanctuaries with advanced ecological technology for optimal habitat conditions.
options.B: Launch educational campaigns to promote bee conservation and awareness.

AA.narrative: Both teams chose to invest in technology for creating bee sanctuaries. This futuristic approach to conservation shows promise, but its cost-effectiveness and long-term impacts remain to be seen.

AB.narrative: One team focused on establishing advanced habitats while the other raised awareness through education. This complementary strategy boosted both short-term conservation efforts and long-term awareness.

BA.narrative: In a well-balanced response, one team raised public awareness while other invested in sanctuary developments. This approach promises good prospects not just for bees, but for biodiversity as a whole.

BB.narrative: Both teams invested in educational campaigns, igniting public awareness and increasing enthusiasm for bee conservation. The way forward now is to translate awareness into concrete preservation actions.
